column13: Add arbitrary information to title box including CHID
column20:
This PR depends on #122.
This PR abstracts the adding of lines of information to the title box (where currently version information is displayed). Using this abstraction a line for CHID is added, along with the GUI, .ini, and Lua controls options for it.
This  also allows for arbitrary information to be added via Lua scripts. The title box holds two kinds of text data, those hardcoded in the program (such as those that already exist) and those added dynamically.
An example of information added dynamically is shown in the script below:
initsmvdata()
print(chid)
print(fdsprefix)

add_title_line(string.format("Date: %s", os.date("%c")))
add_title_line(string.format("CHID Again: %s", chid))

-- calculate the total number of cells
local total_cells = 0
for i,mesh in pairs(meshinfo) do
    local cells = mesh.ibar * mesh.jbar * mesh.kbar
    total_cells = total_cells + cells
end

add_title_line(string.format("No. Cells: %d over  %d meshes", total_cells, nmeshes))

yieldscript()
The results of this script can be seen in this rendering:

I would like to make a change in behaviour so that we can only see whichever pieces of information we like, currently the Smokeview label is compulsory, but that will change behaviour for everybody, so I've kept that separate.
I'm not sure how it should be named, or where to best locate the code, so I've started like this. This is just a draft, but it maintains the current behaviour. Margins and font sizes may need clarification, but that existed before these changes also.

Jake,
looks good.  before I accept it can you change calls to allocate and free memory to use NewMemory and FREEMEMORY (see examples elsewhere in the code).  You will also need to include MALLOC.h in any routine that uses these NewMemory or FREEMEMORY.  I wrote a set of routines (based upon a reference I can't find now) that sit on top of malloc and free that add some rudimentary error checking.  Besides memory that is requested, NewMemory allocates an extra block of memory it uses to store a "guard" byte with a known value.  I also store the name of the routine and location where the allocation occurred..  When smokeview runs in debug mode, and whenever any memory allocation/free operation is performed, all memory blocks are checked to ensure this "guard" byte is correct.  If it is not , I assume that a memory overwrite has occurred and I cause smokview to crash.  This feature has saved me many times!  I also have a CheckMemory directive I sprinkle throughout the code to force a checks of memory blocks.  This checking does not occur in release mode so does not affect performance.  (don't really notice any performance issues in debug mode iether).
Looks like you did it correctly but we'll have to be care about screen space adding the extra title lines.
Let me know if you have any questions.

column20:
This pull request exposes the loaded slice data to Lua. This can be used as in the example code below:
initsmvdata()
-- If the data is not loaded there will be nothing to operate on. This example
-- simply uses the first available slice (at index 0).
loadsliceindex(0)

local slice = get_slice(0)
local label = slice_get_label(slice)
local filename = slice_get_filename(slice)
local times = slice_get_times(slice)

function f(nmax, tbl)
    -- This function will return the number of data points above 60
    -- each frame. This could also performs actions, such as taking screenshots
    -- when certain conditions are met.
    local n = 0;
    for i,v in ipairs(tbl) do
        if (v>60) then
            n = n + 1
        end
    end
    return n
end

-- The function f is applied to the data in each frame of the slice. The value
-- for each frame is returned in a table. This done can be used by
-- the lua script for any purpose such as plotting or further calculations.
local values = slice_data_map_frames(slice, f)

print("filename:", filename)
assert(#times==#values)
for i,v in ipairs(values) do
    print(string.format("at %.2f s there are %i data points above 60",
                        times[i], values[i]))
end
exit()
This script loads a slice, and then counts all the values in that slice over 60 (in this case 60°). There are also a few C functions to apply to slice files that are much faster than custom Lua code, but less flexible. This data can then be plotted, or used in whatever fashion the script chooses. I often use it to plot the area of a domain falling above or below certain threshold.

column13: Add a .travis.yml file for integration with travis-ci
column20:
This is the inclusion of a single text file in the repo root.
I've been using the Travis CI (it's a continuous integration platform) for a while to test changes. I've always maintained it in a separate branch which changes the build system to use only Makefiles (without any shell scripts). However, maintaining it in a separate branch partially defeated the purpose of continuous integration.
Travis integrates directly with github, so if activated it's able to build and test any branch with a .travis.yml file as soon as a commit is pushed. This wouldn't actually affect the firemodels/smv repo (other than the added file) unless Travis is turned on.
There is already Smokebot, but as that only runs at NIST it's not really accessible to test pull requests until they're merged. By adding this .travis.yml file, anybody can test against a common build system by checking a box in their github repo.
P.S. I've based this on #371, as it's likely to be merged and it makes merging simpler.

column20:
This is more of a discussion piece and this code needn't necessarily be merged.
This seems to be the minimum amount of changes necessary to allow for multiple different Smokeview cases to be loaded and unloaded.  The purpose of this patch is to determine which parts of  the logic would need to be changed to support this. This patch has been tested to load multiple times and works, but hasn't been tested exhaustively.
The main architectural difference that needs to occur is to distinguish between initialisation procedures that need to occur for Smokeview itself, and initialisations that occur only for a particular case. If app-wide initialisations are run multiple times they result in errors, as they weren't designed to be run multiple times. In this patch these initialisations were moved from the read procedure into the main function, alongside other app-wide initialisation procedures.
For language and unit initialisations this was simple, but cameras were troublesome because of the way the read procedure interacted with the camera list. In this patch the camera list is initialised in the main function along with all the other initialisations, and then specific cameras, include default cameras, are loaded and added to the list as part of the case loading procedure.
This patch also includes two new data structures that are currently fairly empty, by represent this splitting of application initialisation and case initialisation. column13: Add -std=gnu89 to gcc builds.
column20:
The current code based conforms to the C standard gnu89 (i.e. C89 + GNU extensions), and current build requirments prevent use of C99 features. I would like to add the -std=gnu89 flag to ensure that the builds (and any errors they produced) can be reproduced reliably. This way anyone can compile changes and be sure they will also compile elsewhere (at NIST for example).
This currently only applies gcc as it is the only compiler I can test, but the same flag should be able to be applied to Intel compilers (based on their documentation).
I'm open to suggestions for a more elegant way to do this of course.

build: Trial makefiles for libraries
column20:
Currently, in order to build the library dependencies for Smokeview, the various make_smokeview.sh scripts call test_libs.sh. This script essentially tests for the presence of each library and rebuilds all scripts if any are missing. This is essentially the same job as a makefile, so it makes sense from a maintainability perspective just to use makefiles here as well.

This is more consistent with the rest of the build system, which uses makefiles.
The current implementation can result in libraries being built multiple times if there's a build error (this has bitten me).
By using makefiles it's trivial to enable parallel builds (e.g. with -j 4). This cuts my build time in half.

column13: Remove Fortran
column20:
This is step 1 in a series of patches to remove Fortran code from smokeview. This step is designed to be minimal:

There are no changes to the design or API.
Changes to existing files (i.e. excluding getdata.c and gsmv.c are minimised, consisting mainly of changes of levels of indirection and removal of some variables which are no longer in use.
There are no tests, these will come as a separate patch.

Because of the constraints are above there are a lot of improvements that could be made to the code here, but aren't. Such improvements will come in later patches. To include them here would be to increase the size of the patch and make it more difficult to review.
I'm marking this as work in progress as there is plenty of testing and tweaking to be done, but it's better done in the open.
